title: Tuesday, 23rd July 2019
bodyHTML:
Blank canvas Good morning everyone
11:06 am
BE11:07am

Morning.

Soundbuy Morning
marktime Scorchio
Excel Developer Good morning, automobile stocks up (e.g. BMW 4-5%), what happened?
Patience Good morning
IMP.GLD Inmarsat please thank you
BornCynic Good morning BE - do you have anything on PZ Cussons in your inbox please?
VV75 morning
marktime Shake Fevertree
BE11:08am

Where to begin? How about with this social calendar entry from Nicholas Foulkes in the Weekend FT, dated 1st July 2000.

MassimoJ Anything on the straight bat from IG this morning?
BE11:08am

Thursday

July 6

It is the big one - the mother of all garden parties, the night when politics, right-wing rhetoric, transatlantic glamour and copious quantities of booze collide - the Spectator Summer Party.

Tonight, the best Tory prime minister we never had, Boris Johnson, and The Spectator's first lady "Dame" Kimberly Fortier, host the hottest summer ticket, with the exception of the Cartier Polo and the De Beers Diamond day at Ascot.

The ratio of guests per square foot of standing room makes the Northern Line seem positively agoraphobic and if there have ever been any canapes, I have never seen them.

Nevertheless, there is an enduring glamour about it and this year's event is already looking up as Krug is rumoured to be supplying the quaff - next year it might even be Cristal.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

That was only his third ever mention in the FT -- the previous two were a radio review and a mention of his appointment to the Spectator chair -- and we'd already pinned him as leadership class.

Soundbuy Fevertree - hmmmm.....
BE11:10am

That's the kind of insight worth paying for.

BornCynic Those "perfect weekend" bits in the magazine always wanted to make me bin it as quickly as I could. After shouting "eat more food" at the female models in the adverts..........
BE11:11am

(Though bear in mind you don't pay for this bit, so the insight is limited accordingly.)

undefined

Alchemy30 How long before DM runs a Pepsi story ?
11:16 am
BE11:16am

So, we get a light warning in the guidance. Here's Jefferies to summarise.

BE11:16am

What's new? 1H19 results. Co reports 1H19 sales +13% to £117m (Jef +15% to £119.9m, Facset £120m). UK +5% (Jef +8%), Europe +13% (Jef +14%), US +31% (Jef +38%) after F18 +21%, ROW +49% (Jef +30%). Adj EBITDA +8% to £36.7m (Jef +9% to £36.9m, Factset £36.5m) . EPS 24.3p (Jef 24.7p, Facset 25.0p).

BE11:17am

F19 guidance. Company is "mindful of the tough comps over the remainder of the summer in the UK, board anticipates that the outcome for the year will be in line with expectations". Growth constituents for 2H could evolve vs 1H. UK has easier comps in 2H so should accelerate, Europe could accelerate on contract wins/phasing, US underlying acceleration but less FX upside, RoW should normalise on phasing. All in all, mid-teens growth feasible with EBITDA margin 31%. We believe street EPS could drift modestly from 58.2p towards 57.4p.

nightingale20201 morning all
11:17 am
BE11:17am

UK growth normalising and weather headwinds. UK (51% of sales) 1H sales +5% to £60.7m (Jef +8% to £62.7m) held back by poor weather and category moderation. This implies 2H +14% to reach our F19 forecast +10%. 2H benefits from easier comps (1H18 +73% vs 2H18 +41%). FEVR now holds 39% share in the off-trade (62k distribution points up from 58k F18) and 45% in the on-trade.

BE11:17am

US growth accelerating. US (17% of sales) org sales +24% (Jef +32%) in-line with F18 +24% and reported growth +31% (Jef +38%). This implies the co needs +35% in 2H to reach our F19 forecast of +33%. Off-trade distribution gains across national accounts Target, Kroger & Walmart and regional chains e.g., Publix. On trade new account wins with SGWS under a "fast start initiative" and a broad range of co-promo activities. Elderflower & Mediterranean greater than 50% sales and distribution growth.

BE11:17am

Europe positive growth driven by younger gin markets. Europe (25% of sales) 1H org sales +14% (Jef +14%) to £29m (Jef £29.4m). This implies the co needs to deliver +33% in 2H to reach our F19 forecast of +23.7% with lumpiness in buy-in patterns causing volatility in growth between 1H/2H, co is confident in achieving an acceleration in 2H. Increased investment adding new listings across Germany, France and Spain. Transition in Germany from importer to an agency agreement with a local distribution partner.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

ROW driving significant growth. ROW (7% of sales) very good growth 1H org sales +49% (Jef +30%) to £7.9m (Jef £6.9m) led by Australia and Canada. Increased investment in personnel with senior managers appointed in Australia and Canada and a new regional director for Asia.

Valuation. Calendar 2020E PE 34x, PEG 2.4x, price to sales 7.8x.

FATDAZ re fever tree am i missing something shouldn't a warm summer boost sales as we all crave long drinks with ice?
BE11:19am

7.8x sales for an FMCG company that's selling wholesale mostly into a market existed pretty much unchanged for a couple of centuries, sure, cool ewev.

BornCynic On another subject today I learned about "space adaptation syndrome":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_adaptation_syndromeDo you think someone has told Richard Branson to expect a lot of people throwing up in his shiny new "spacecraft".

BE11:20am

Investec:

marktime "weather headwinds" strewth
BE11:20am

Overall, there are no significant changes to our FY19E or FY20E forecasts, but these numbers show encouraging progress from the international operations, in particular some early distribution wins in the US. Our DCF TP adjusts to 3650p on longer term growth phasing, but we reiterate our BUY stance.

BE11:20am

Numis:

11:20 am
BE11:21am

Fever-Tree’s interim results should provide reassurance that, whilst the UK is moderating off a high base, achieving 5% growth, the rest of the business represents an exciting medium-term growth opportunity, with sales 23% higher in H1 2019, driven by an encouraging US performance. The global trends underpinning simple long mixed drinks continue to support increased penetration by premium mixers. We believe that Fever-Tree's leading position in the category and broad portfolio of mixers means it is well placed to capitalise on this opportunity. We have rebalanced our regional forecasts, but make no material changes to group forecasts. We think the current valuation represents an excellent entry point to the long-term growth opportunity. Buy, 3,600p TP

GG Mediclinic again!
BE11:22am

(@GG: the stocks you mention aren't moving on no news. I'm not exactly sure what you're wanting.)

BE11:23am

MOST.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

We expect a positive share price reaction as Fever-Tree's H1 19 result provides some relief for shares which have lost almost 30% of their value since May. Overall revenue grew by +13% with an acceleration in the US (+31% in H1 19 vs 21% in FY18, driven by distribution gains) offset by soft performance in the UK (+5%) and Europe (+13%). Regarding the UK specifically, whilst 5% is disappointing we note that the weather has had a "dampening effect on growth rates", which is not unique to Fever-Tree within the beverages space. Management expects growth to accelerate in H2 in the UK as well as Europe, which was impacted by phasing (underlying depletions are running ahead of shipments in H1). Overall, management expects full year performance to be inline with board expectations, which is in line with previous guidance. We do not expect any change to consensus based on H1 19 results. . Fever-Tree trades on 34x CY20 PE.

BE11:23am

And RBC:

BE11:24am

Fever-Tree ‘s 1H19 results missed consensus expectations. The driving factor behind this is the UK which suffered unfavourable weather and tough comparatives.
Organic revenue growth in the US and Europe also missed consensus expectations. Given that sell side sales expectations have been lowered in recent months, a 4%
miss on the top line is disappointing in our view.
Our positive stance has been predicated on Fever-Tree’s US opportunity. However US organic revenue growth has not accelerated and remains at 24%, in line with 2018.
Organic revenue growth of 24% was in line with our forecasts given that we expect US acceleration to pick up in 2H19, however it is a miss relative to consensus
expectations.
Fever-Tree talks about an “encouraging first half for the Group” and particularly the US where it has “made significant distribution gains and operational progress”. We
are confused by the messaging given a miss vs consensus expecta ons for US and Group organic revenue growth.
In this context, guidance for a full year outcome in line with management expectations is unhelpful. Particularly given that they highlight continued tough comparatives
in 2H19 when in fact the UK comparatives significantly ease. Fever-Tree achieved 73% UK organic revenue growth in 1H18 and 41% in 2H18.

GG Flow
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Our confidence in a progressive acceleration in the US is increasing as Fever-Tree secures marketing partnerships with key premium spirits brands and establishes a strong distribution network.

BE11:25am

Here's my thinking. If your sales are going to be influenced to this extent by a slightly damp spring, try not to trade at 34x 2020.

BE11:25am

Just a thought.

Irish HF guy FeverTree EPS for 2019 should be at least 50p so 42x PE CY2019, 34x for 2020 seems ambitious
11:30 am
BE11:30am

Oh god, it's a year of transition.

BE11:30am

 PZ Cussons has delivered FY19 results in line with expectations. Adj PBT was
£69.8m vs our forecast of £70m. EPS were 13p and the FY dividend was
maintained at 8.28p. The group has announced some restatements of PY
numbers referencing changes in accounting policy but also some prior year
adjustments around goodwill accounting. Net debt was as expected, at £152m.
 Regionally, Africa remained weak, reporting a small operating loss. Europe was
robust, operating profits were 6% lower but this was after increasing marketing
investment. Asia reported good progress in margins and profits.
 The group has announced a strategic review to deliver increased focus and
scale and to accelerate the return to profitable growth. We expect FY20 to be a
year of transition, with further investment in key areas expected, so growth is
more likely to resume in FY21. The group is not assuming any improvement in
underlying trading conditions in any markets, but increased marketing spend is
expected to drive some growth from FY21.
 Key areas of focus within the range in future will be Personal Care and Beauty
group wide, and Electricals and Palm oil in Africa. Homecare will continue to be
important from a scale perspective. However, Food and Nutrition (FY19 revenue
£110m) is an area which could see some disposal activity. The group will also
be looking at its cost base to see if there is scope for further streamlining.
 We have adjusted numbers for FY20E/FY21E. We assume unchanged profit
now in FY20E (£70.2m, down from £76m), but assume growth resumes in
FY21E with PBT now £75.9m (from £80.5m)

BE11:31am

And Caz.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

PZ Cussons’ FY19 results are in line with our expectations. Adjusted PBT of £69.8m (JPMe: £70.6m) is around
the level guided at the 1H19 results. In our view the key message is the announced strategic change which
involves: 1) focus on Personal Care and Beauty brands in geographies that can scale growth; 2) Simplification
of the Nigerian activities; 3) Disposal of non-core brands. Management expects conditions in key markets to
remain challenging, and 2019/20 to be an important transitional year.
 Results are mixed across markets. Adjusted operating profit of £76.5m was down 10.7% y/y (-9.7% on
constant currency basis). It was negatively impacted by weak conditions in Africa (-115.9% y/y; -117.7% on
constant currency), while Europe & The Americas was down 6.1% y/y (-6.2% cc) and Asia performed strong,
up 9.7 (+13.7% cc).
 Europe & The Americas: Beauty was strong, especially driven by St Tropez introduction in the US.
However, performance for the region was offset by increased marketing spend in the UK and weaker
performance in Food & Nutrition in Greece.
 Asia Pacific: Strong performance was driven by Indonesia (especially Cussons Baby) and Australia (margin
improvement across categories), partially offset by impact of lower revenue in the Middle East.
 Africa: Lower revenue in Personal and Home Care categories, and increased operating costs predominantly
relating to previously highlighted charges associated with port access issues in Lagos.
 Net debt improved to £152.2m (JPMe £152.9m) from £165.7m at FY18.
 Dividend of 8.28p is unchanged y/y and in line with expectations (JPMe 8.28p).
 Reported PBT of £37.0m (down 37.5% y/y from £59.2m) was impacted by non-cash impairment of
intangible assets (five:am in Australia and Nutricima in Nigeria).
 More details on the strategic change will be announced in the 2019 Annual Report and Accounts.
 Outlook points out challenging conditions in key markets will likely remain.

The UK government has intervened in the takeover of satellite company Inmarsat on national security grounds.

Jeremy Wright, the culture secretary, has issued a public interest intervention notice on the $6bn sale of the British satellite company to a consortium of private equity companies and pension funds.

The minister said he had received representations from the secretary of state for defence, the business secretary and the foreign secretary before issuing the notice. The Competition & Markets Authority has also opened a review.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

UK government interventions on national security grounds are rare. New rules for takeovers were introduced in 2018 in response to concerns that sensitive technology was being snapped up by foreign buyers, particularly Chinese companies.

The takeover of Northern Aerospace by Chinese-owned Gardners last year was the last intervention on such grounds, according to the government. That deal was cleared.

BE11:39am

What are the concerns? No idea!

BE11:39am

The Inmarsat sale to a consortium of buyers based in the UK, US and Canada was not initially thought to be problematic but concerns have grown in recent weeks.

BE11:43am

· Support Inmarsat’s continued role as a leader in the space sector;

· Procure that the majority of key strategic decisions of both Connect and Inmarsat are taken in the UK;

· Procure that Inmarsat and its subsidiaries (the “Inmarsat Group”) maintain in the United Kingdom those areas of Inmarsat’s global network operations centres that, as at the Effective Date, are located in the UK and have been identified by the SoS as being important to remain in the UK (the “Core Global Network Operations”);

· Procure that the Core Global Network Operations shall (i) continue to perform substantially the same functions as are conducted at the Effective Date; (ii) retain substantially the same skilled engineering resources which as at the Effective Date are based in the UK for the purposes of operating such Core Global Network Operations, and (iii) remain the principal Core Global Network Operations of Inmarsat; and

· Procure that the members of the Inmarsat Group comply with their respective obligations in respect of certain commercial contracts identified by the SoS as being important in order to support the Inmarsat Group’s investment in capital expenditure and supply chain maintenance.

BE11:49am

IQE^ (IQE, NR, CNP) - Wireless qualification update - new qualifications for Asian supply chains. The company announces the successful qualification, commencement of initial production and receipt of additional orders of wireless products for Asian supply chains. As previously communicated, because of the current trade situation between the US and China, supply chains are being redeveloped across the globe. This has had an impact on sales volumes for IQE's products, as global customers adjust to these new supply chain situations and IQE becomes qualified in these new supply chains. However, IQE remains well placed to support these changes because of its diverse global footprint, with manufacturing plants in the US, Europe and importantly in Asia (Taiwan and Singapore), and its powerful portfolio of wireless products. IQE has now qualified with a major customer in Asia for new Asia-centric supply chains for Heterojunction Bipolar Transistors (HBTs). These are used as Power Amplifiers (PAs) in mobile handsets, wifi hotspots and other wireless devices. Initial production for this customer has now commenced and additional qualification of significantly higher production capacity is underway from the newly installed capacity at IQE's facility in Hsinchu, Taiwan. In addition, significant additional orders have been received by IQE from a second Asian customer, specifically addressing increased demand from Asian OEMs. Finally, IQE's Singapore operation has also completed qualification of a new Asian customer for Pseudomorphic High Electron Mobility Transistors (pHEMTs). These are also used in wireless devices and networks and IQE has already received initial orders for production.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

(@cheeckychappy: following orders. neutral face.)

BE11:50am

And Peel Hunt.

BE11:50am

Back in June, we flagged how IQE’s broad global footprint can benefit from tariff-driven changes to the global supply chains. Today’s announcement of a Wireless (Power Amplifiers) qualification with a “major customer in Asia” for an Asian-centric supply chain is a proof-point for that view. Initial production is said to have already begun with the expectations for a ramp-up at the expanded Taiwan facility. IQE also points to additional Wireless orders being received from a second Asian OEM. It was also good to see IQE’s pHEMTs (a type of a higher performance transistor used in Wireless) technology gaining a new Asian customer via IQE’s Singapore operation. Collectively, these deals demonstrate IQE’s ability to jump on the newly emerging (in response to trade-war) Asia-centric supply chains. We also note IQE’s formation of an executive management board made of CTO, COO, head of Wireless (and emerging products) and the head of Photonics (and infrared). We laud this step-up in its governance and management control systems. With the semis bell-weather TSMC flagging the bottoming of the market, AMS confirming the H2 19 3D sensing ramp, and pressure on the US administration from companies like Google to solve the Huawei issue in a timely manner, despite the continued macro and political uncertainties, we see no reason why IQE’s shares should continue to underperform (see chart #1) its peer group.

BE11:56am

Tesco. This period gives us 50 out of the 91 day Q2 period. Based on these 7 weeks, the trend implies -2.0% LfL, down from our previous estimate of +1%; given that the World Cup / hot summer comp weeks are now largely out of the way and we expect the remainder of Q2 to be better, we revise our estimate to -1% LfL for Q2 2019. We rate Tesco Outperform with a TP of £2.90.

Sainsbury's. This period's data gives us 15 days out of their 84-day Q2 period, which is not enough to make a reasonable projection of Q2 trading performance. Our last LfL estimate for Q2 was -2.2%. We rate Sainsbury's Market-Perform with a £2.50 TP.

Morrisons. This period gives us 70 days out of 91-day Q2 period. Kantar data suggest a -2.4% drop, and so by a similar logic to with Tesco, we update our LfL forecast for Q2 to -1.5%, from our previous +1.4%. We rate Morrisons Market-Perform with a £2.40 TP.

Santander reported NII of EUR8.95bn for Q2, up 3.1% QOQ and above
consensus estimates (EUR8.77bn). Total income was up 2.2% QOQ to
EUR12.35bn, net operating income +3.1% QOQ to EUR6.52bn while profit
before tax tumbled by 18.7% QOQ to EUR2.93bn and net profit (parent)
was down -24.4% QOQ to EUR1.39bn (est. EUR1.27bn). Q2 was affected
by EUR706m of net charges (mainly restructuring costs in Spain and the
UK). Excluding this impact, underlying profit was EUR2.09bn (+8% QOQ)
and, excluding the contribution to the SRF, underlying profit would have
risen by 16%. The efficiency ratio was stable QOQ at 47.2% (47.6% in Q1
2019, 47.5% in H1 2018). The ROE was down slightly to 7.79% versus
7.85% three months ago (8.24% at end-June 2018).

Patience @Sultan but if Fevertree grows too much it loses cachet and hence margin :-(
BE12:01pm

The cost of credit ended Q2 at 0.98% (0.99% on prior year) and the NPL
ratio improved for the eighth consecutive quarter at 3.51% versus 3.62%
in Q1 2019, 3.73% at YE 2018 and 3.92% in H1 2018. The coverage ratio
was stable QOQ at 68%. The FL CET1 was up slightly at 11.30% (11.23% in
Q1 2019), but stable versus YE 2018 (11.30%). Santander generated 11bps
organically in Q2 (+29bps in H1) after absorbing regulatory impacts and
restructuring costs (-20 bps). The FL total ratio stood at 14.80% (14.82% in
Q1 2019/14.77% YE 2018).

BE12:01pm

Santander announced changes in its organisational structure with three
regions (Europe, North and South America), ring fencing in the UK and an
acceleration in its digitalisation process with the creation of one global
platform. The group confirmed the targets presented at its Investor Day
(April): additional annual cost savings of EUR1.2bn (of which EUR1bn in
Europe), EUR20bn of investments in the next four years in digitalisation, a
ROTE of 13-15% in the medium term (11.02% in Q1 2019), a reduced
efficiency ratio at 43-45% and the FL CET1 ratio maintained at 11-12%
(11.3% in Q1). Santander said it currently complies with MREL
requirements.

BE12:02pm

Santander’s 2Q19 conference call has just finished. For us the key takeaways were as follows:
ECB rate cuts (=): SAN is already passing negative rates through to its
1.institutional (corporate) clients, but only to their non-operational deposits (operational deposits remain remunerated at 0%); with regard to the possibility of charging households/retail depositors as well, management mentioned that it is too early to comment as this topic is not yet on the table.
CCyB (=): A 25bps hike in the countercyclical capital buffer (CCyB) in all the
2.European countries in which they operate at the same time would translate into an increase of 8bps to the Group’s capital requirements.
Capital (=): SAN expects additional (negative) regulatory impacts worth
3.20-30bps of CET1 in 2H19 (2/3 TRIM-related, 1/3 from other minor impacts) to be more than offset through organic capital generation and further management actions, as guided during the bank’s Investor Day in April; all in, management reiterated plans to (1) grow its CET1 B3FL ratio this year, so 4Q19 greater than 4Q18; and to (2) reach its 11.5% target as soon as possible.
Restructuring costs (=): Additional restructuring costs in Spain are expected to
4.be at €200mn (pay-back of 2.3 years) in 2020; in the UK, where the bank plans to reduce costs by c.€400mn, pay-back is estimated to be at c.1 year.
Margins (+): Management is optimistic about front-book-margins, which they’ve
5.seen stabilizing over the last couple of quarters: (1) In Spain, they expect competition from domestic players to slow down on the back of lower-for-longer rates, which may help improve pricing dynamics locally; (2) in the UK, margin pressures are concentrated in the SVR book while front-book margins have been stable over the last two quarters (after compressing to 90bps from 130bps a year ago). Management mentioned they have room for manoeuvre (via lower funding costs) through the 123 account and other products.
